explanation:
OS_console_internal_record_t - Need the struct definition (fields, types, and qualifiers such as volatile) to determine whether ReadPos/WritePos/BufSize/BufBase are modifiable and whether reads are subject to external updates (affects whether StartPos/EndPos can be invariant).

OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET - Determine whether this macro/function returns a pointer to the live console record or a copy. If it returns a copy then console (and thus EndPos) would be invariant within the function; if it returns a pointer, EndPos may reflect shared state.

OS_console_table - The object/table used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its layout/semantics can affect whether the returned console pointer aliases shared mutable state or a snapshot.

OS_object_token_t - Type definition for the token and any semantics (e.g., indexing behavior) to understand how the table lookup is performed and whether the lookup can fail or produce a copy vs. reference.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken - The call-graph shows this is related to object-table access; its implementation details may be what OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET uses. Needed to confirm whether the lookup yields a live index/pointer or a static value.

OS_BSP_Lock_Impl and OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl - The lock/unlock semantics determine whether other contexts can modify console->WritePos while this function runs. If the lock serializes writers with readers, EndPos is invariant with respect to other threads during the locked region; if not, EndPos may change asynchronously.

OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl - This BSP output function may block, yield, or call other kernel primitives that allow preemption/other threads to run; its behavior affects whether the loop body can permit external updates to EndPos even while locked (or if the lock is a no-op in practice).

OS_ConsoleWrite - One of the likely writers that increments/updates console->WritePos. To prove the loop condition is not an invariant you must inspect functions that modify WritePos (producers) and their synchronization with the reader.

OS_ConsoleTask_Entry - The console task entry is another potential modifier of console state; inspect it to see how it updates WritePos and whether it coordinates with the same locking used here.

OS_Console_CopyOut - Called by OS_ConsoleWrite (per call graph) and likely responsible for copying data into the console buffer and advancing WritePos; needed to identify where WritePos is modified.

OS_ConsoleWakeup_Impl - May be involved in notifying the console output task or writers; needed to understand concurrency ordering and whether writers can change WritePos while this function holds its lock.

Reasoning summary: The MISRA rule concerns whether the while-controlling expression (StartPos != EndPos) can be invariant. To decide this you must know (a) whether EndPos is a live, shared value or a local snapshot, (b) whether StartPos is modified (it is locally), and (c) whether other threads/functions can change EndPos during the loop or whether the BSP lock prevents that. The symbols above provide the type/layout of console state, how it is obtained, which functions update WritePos, and the locking/side-effect behavior needed to determine compliance.
